articles.headline: Set to Lift Interest Rate, Fed Embraces Investors’ Optimism
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chief’s declaration followed mounting signals from policy makers that the central bank had accelerated its timetable for action.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chief’s declaration followed mounting signals from policy makers that the central bank had accelerated its timetable for action.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is poised to raise its benchmark interest rate in mid-March, significantly sooner than investors had expected, as it moves to keep pace with a wave of economic optimism that started with the election of President Trump.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Arkansas Rushes to Execute 8 Men in the Space of 10 Days
articles.snippet: As the state rushes to beat the expiration date of its supply of a lethal-injection drug, the rate of scheduled executions is unmatched since capital punishment resumed in 1977.
articles.abstract: As the state rushes to beat the expiration date of its supply of a lethal-injection drug, the rate of scheduled executions is unmatched since capital punishment resumed in 1977.
articles.lead_paragraph: The state of Arkansas plans to put to death eight inmates over a span of 10 days next month, a pace of executions unequaled in recent American history and brought about by a looming expiration date for a drug used by the state for lethal injections.
articles.byline: By Matthew Haag and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Signet Jewelers’ Balance Sheet Gets Extra Sparkle
articles.snippet: An unusual accounting method helps the parent of Jared, Kay and Zales make its loan portfolio look shinier than it should.
articles.abstract: An unusual accounting method helps the parent of Jared, Kay and Zales make its loan portfolio look shinier than it should.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of business, bad news often surfaces serially: You see a cockroach in your kitchen; as the days go by, you meet his relatives.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide
articles.snippet: A program uses data Uber collected to evade law enforcement in cities that resist the ride-hailing service, some current and former Uber employees said.
articles.abstract: A program uses data Uber collected to evade law enforcement in cities that resist the ride-hailing service, some current and former Uber employees said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber has for years engaged in a worldwide program to deceive the authorities in markets where its low-cost ride-hailing service was resisted by law enforcement or, in some instances, had been banned.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Jim Rogers, Intrepid Investor, Finds Bumpy Road to North Korea
articles.snippet: The famous investor sees promise in the isolated country but claims he was surprised to find that a firm doing business there listed him as a shareholder.
articles.abstract: The famous investor sees promise in the isolated country but claims he was surprised to find that a firm doing business there listed him as a shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China was an economic backwater when Jim Rogers began traveling its dusty byways more than three decades ago. Still, Mr. Rogers, a former partner of George Soros, saw its promise.
articles.byline: By Patrick Boehler and Ryan Mcmorrow

articles.headline: How Gorsuch the Clerk Met Kennedy the Justice: A Tale of Luck
articles.snippet: Neil M. Gorsuch worked as a law clerk for two justices, including Anthony M. Kennedy, in the early 1990s, giving him a privileged look at the court’s workings.
articles.abstract: Neil M. Gorsuch worked as a law clerk for two justices, including Anthony M. Kennedy, in the early 1990s, giving him a privileged look at the court’s workings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a stroke of luck that landed Neil M. Gorsuch in the chambers of Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on a summer day nearly a quarter-century ago.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Trump Team’s Links to Russia Crisscross in Washington
articles.snippet: A growing list of contacts between the president’s associates and Russia is drawing increasing scrutiny, a furor that Mr. Trump called a “total witch hunt.”
articles.abstract: A growing list of contacts between the president’s associates and Russia is drawing increasing scrutiny, a furor that Mr. Trump called a “total witch hunt.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the 2016 campaign, Donald J. Trump’s second campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, had regular communications with his longtime associate — a former Russian military translator in Kiev who has been investigated in Ukraine on suspicion of being a Russian intelligence agent.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Campus Backlash After Leaders of Black Colleges Meet With Trump
articles.snippet: Some students criticized the visit as benefiting the president more than the universities, and suggested that the meeting was little more than a photo op.
articles.abstract: Some students criticized the visit as benefiting the president more than the universities, and suggested that the meeting was little more than a photo op.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a scalding message, painted on a university campus sidewalk this week: “Welcome to the Trump plantation. Overseer: Wayne A. I. Frederick.”
articles.byline: By Anemona Hartocollis and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Blockchain: A Better Way to Track Pork Chops, Bonds, Bad Peanut Butter?
articles.snippet: Walmart is testing real-world uses for the arcane technology behind the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, but significant challenges remain.
articles.abstract: Walmart is testing real-world uses for the arcane technology behind the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, but significant challenges remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frank Yiannas has spent years looking in vain for a better way to track lettuce, steaks and snack cakes from farm and factory to the shelves of Walmart, where he is the vice president for food safety. When the company dealt with salmonella outbreaks, it often took weeks to trace where the bad ingredients came from.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Samsung Bribery Scandal Threatens South Korea Success Story
articles.snippet: Business and government worked hand in hand to rebuild the war-torn country. Now that same recipe fosters corruption and holds back the Asian Tiger.
articles.abstract: Business and government worked hand in hand to rebuild the war-torn country. Now that same recipe fosters corruption and holds back the Asian Tiger.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Jay Y. Lee, heir to one of the world’s biggest corporate empires, followed in the footsteps of his prominent father. He took charge of key businesses. He hobnobbed with his country’s president. He brought in new ideas.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: War Consumes South Sudan, a Young Nation Cracking Apart
articles.snippet: Conflict has spread to even peaceful areas, and government-backed militias burn down villages, drive millions from their homes, and massacre and gang-rape civilians.
articles.abstract: Conflict has spread to even peaceful areas, and government-backed militias burn down villages, drive millions from their homes, and massacre and gang-rape civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAMBIO, South Sudan — Simon Burete was weeding his peanut field a few weeks ago when he saw smoke coming from his house. He ran as fast as he could.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Trump Inherits a Secret Cyberwar Against North Korean Missiles
articles.snippet: The United States has been trying to sabotage North Korea’s missile program. President Trump must decide what to do next.
articles.abstract: The United States has been trying to sabotage North Korea’s missile program. President Trump must decide what to do next.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, President Barack Obama ordered Pentagon officials to step up their cyber and electronic strikes against North Korea’s missile program in hopes of sabotaging test launches in their opening seconds.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Trump, Offering No Evidence, Says Obama Tapped His Phones
articles.snippet: President Trump called former President Barack Obama a “bad (or sick) guy” as he leveled an explosive claim about election-season wiretapping.
articles.abstract: President Trump called former President Barack Obama a “bad (or sick) guy” as he leveled an explosive claim about election-season wiretapping.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump on Saturday accused former President Barack Obama of tapping his phones at Trump Tower the month before the election, leveling the explosive allegation without offering any evidence.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Migrants Confront Judgment Day Over Old Deportation Orders
articles.snippet: Unauthorized immigrants who have stayed in the United States after being ordered deported have emerged as an easy target of the Trump administration’s aims.
articles.abstract: Unauthorized immigrants who have stayed in the United States after being ordered deported have emerged as an easy target of the Trump administration’s aims.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are a little more than two weeks between Juan, an electrician in the Bronx, and the date he cannot forget: March 21, 2017, at 8 a.m., when the federal government has told him to report for deportation.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Comey Asks Justice Dept. to Reject Trump’s Wiretapping Claim
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. director wants the Justice Department to refute Mr. Trump’s contention that Barack Obama ordered the tapping of his phones, a claim that Mr. Comey says is false, officials said.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. director wants the Justice Department to refute Mr. Trump’s contention that Barack Obama ordered the tapping of his phones, a claim that Mr. Comey says is false, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, asked the Justice Department this weekend to publicly reject President Trump’s assertion that President Barack Obama ordered the tapping of Mr. Trump’s phones, senior American officials said on Sunday. Mr. Comey has argued that the highly charged claim is false and must be corrected, they said, but the department has not released any such statement.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Leashes Come Off Wall Street, Gun Sellers, Polluters and More
articles.snippet: In a flurry of deregulation, the Trump administration has already suspended or reversed more than 90 rules. And industry is clamoring for more.
articles.abstract: In a flurry of deregulation, the Trump administration has already suspended or reversed more than 90 rules. And industry is clamoring for more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Giants in telecommunications, like Verizon and AT&T, will not have to take “reasonable measures” to ensure that their customers’ Social Security numbers, web browsing history and other personal information are not stolen or accidentally released.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Stocks Are Up 5 Percent Under Trump. So How Long Will the Rally Last?
articles.snippet: Looking closely at what is required for the president’s promised big initiatives, some hedge fund managers are bracing for a sell-off.
articles.abstract: Looking closely at what is required for the president’s promised big initiatives, some hedge fund managers are bracing for a sell-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks have marched higher and higher — up 5 percent since President Trump took office six weeks ago — and the rally has become one of his favorite boasts. And there is plenty of economic data to justify the ebullience.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Time Inc. Plots a Future Beyond Its Heyday, as Suitors Line Up
articles.snippet: Is a new chief executive’s zeal enough to save an empire that once propelled the national conversation but has been struggling for relevance in the digital era?
articles.abstract: Is a new chief executive’s zeal enough to save an empire that once propelled the national conversation but has been struggling for relevance in the digital era?
articles.lead_paragraph: Onstage at a recent industry conference with the longtime leaders of the country’s biggest magazine publishers, Rich Battista, the new chief executive of Time Inc., did not seem the outsider. Tieless, with legs crossed, he ticked off his company’s latest accomplishments — robust digital growth, updated advertising capabilities — with the swagger of a knowing publishing chieftain.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Sexist Political Criticism Finds a New Target: Kellyanne Conway
articles.snippet: Attacks on powerful women, on both sides of the aisle, often take the same form — angry, sexist language. Misogyny, it seems, is bipartisan.
articles.abstract: Attacks on powerful women, on both sides of the aisle, often take the same form — angry, sexist language. Misogyny, it seems, is bipartisan.
articles.lead_paragraph: What powerful political woman is mocked for her clothes, is the target of pictures on Twitter depicting her as haggard and is routinely called a witch and a bitch?
articles.byline: By Susan Chira

articles.headline: Automakers Near a Victory on Rollback of Fuel Standards
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s expected move on emissions and mileage targets would remove a costly mandate, though some efficiency efforts would proceed.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s expected move on emissions and mileage targets would remove a costly mandate, though some efficiency efforts would proceed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Automakers appear to be on the verge of a rare victory in their long-term effort to reduce government regulations on new cars and trucks.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Ex-Employees Note a Hint of Turmoil in Bridgewater’s Recipe for Success
articles.snippet: It’s not every firm where a top executive is accused of lying on a video for every employee to see. But that’s how Ray Dalio runs Bridgewater Associates, according to former employees.
articles.abstract: It’s not every firm where a top executive is accused of lying on a video for every employee to see. But that’s how Ray Dalio runs Bridgewater Associates, according to former employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not every workplace where a top executive is accused of lying on a video for every employee to see. It is also unusual for a company founder to fire an employee in a group email and then later dismiss it as simply a joke.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: A Conspiracy Theory’s Journey From Talk Radio to Trump’s Twitter
articles.snippet: President Trump’s allegation that the Obama administration wiretapped his phones began as a rant on conservative talk radio and then spread to Breitbart News.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s allegation that the Obama administration wiretapped his phones began as a rant on conservative talk radio and then spread to Breitbart News.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It began at 6 p.m. Thursday as a conspiratorial rant on conservative talk radio: President Barack Obama had used the “instrumentalities of the federal government” to wiretap the Republican seeking to succeed him. This “is the big scandal,” Mark Levin, the host, told his listeners.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Peugeot Maker’s Deal for G.M.’s Opel Faces Political Headwinds
articles.snippet: The possibility of job cuts and factory closures in Europe could spark nationalist appeals.
articles.abstract: The possibility of job cuts and factory closures in Europe could spark nationalist appeals.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Turning a French carmaker and its German rival into a global auto giant would be tough under any circumstances. But the deal by PSA Group of France on Monday to buy General Motors’ Opel and Vauxhall brands has the added complexity of politics.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Data Firm Says ‘Secret Sauce’ Aided Trump; Many Scoff
articles.snippet: The big-data company Cambridge Analytica says it has the ability to predict the political leanings of every American adult, but how well it works remains unproved.
articles.abstract: The big-data company Cambridge Analytica says it has the ability to predict the political leanings of every American adult, but how well it works remains unproved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing before political and business leaders in New York last fall, Alexander Nix promised a revolution.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Major Case on Transgender Rights
articles.snippet: The justices vacated an appeals court decision in favor of a transgender boy, Gavin Grimm, and sent the case back for further consideration.
articles.abstract: The justices vacated an appeals court decision in favor of a transgender boy, Gavin Grimm, and sent the case back for further consideration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prompted by the Trump administration’s reversal of the federal government’s position on transgender rights, the Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would not decide whether a transgender boy in Virginia could use the boys’ bathroom at his high school.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak
